data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Version 1703 Build 15063.608

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create `launch.json` with the following contents:  
```json
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "typescript",
            "tsconfig": "tsconfig.json",
            "group": {
                "kind": "build",
                "isDefault": true
            }
        }
    ]
}
```
2. Run the build task
3. Produces: `/usr/bin/bash: c:UsersrobertCodeNodegraphicsnode_modules.bintsc.cmd: command not found` - (notice how all the directories are run together with no directory separator) in the console(I have the shell set to use git bash, rather than `cmd.exe`)


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: TypeScript version selector can get into bad state after deleting workspace root
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (81fc22ec957de26d2bf6aada3f16f04e0164741c, 2017-10-03T22:47:28.178Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
EditorConfig|Edi|0.10.1
vscode-wakatime|Wak|1.1.16
vscode-icontheme-nomo-dark|be5|1.3.2
tslint|eg2|1.0.9
php-debug|fel|1.11.1
php-intellisense|fel|1.5.1
java|red|0.11.0
sourcegraph|sou|1.0.9

(1 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add three roots `removed`, `notremoved` and `notremoved2` with `typescript` installed
2. Select a typescript version installed in the `removed` folder
3. Remove the folder `removed`

My workspace file after that looks like this:
```json
{
	"folders": [
		{
			"path": "removed"
		},
		{
			"path": "notremoved"
		},
		{
			"path": "notremoved2"
		}
	],
	"settings": {
		"typescript.tsdk": "removed/node_modules/typescript/lib"
	}
}
```

Note how the setting still points to the `removed` folder.

Now everytime that workspace is opened you get this error:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10532611/31193814-0a321bc6-a8fa-11e7-9b26-16e856101a83.png)

Notice how it combines `removed` and `notremoved`: `/Users/felix/notremoved/removed/node_modules/typescript/lib`

The same weird path combination now happens in the version selector:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10532611/31193997-9877177e-a8fa-11e7-8ede-a126aae76716.png)


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: [Feature Request] Indication what caused TextDocumentContentChangeEvent
data.body:
I am currently developing a plugin that replaces patterns of typed text. This basically works quite fine, but it does not work well with undo and redo at all. Lets assume I replace every typed double quote (") with some specific string. The first problem shows up when undoing this, because one could end up in a loop (because typing and undoing triggers the same type of event, TextDocumentContentChangeEvent). Redoing is causes the next problems. And all of them are basically caused by the fact, that I cannot tell what caused the text change.

**I think, it would be very useful in general to have some indication what actually caused firing of a TextDocumentContentChangeEvent, whether is was typing, undoing, redoing or something else. This could be an additional flag to any TextDocumentContentChangeEvent instance.**

What do others think about this?

data.title: problem with uncomment 'rem' in *.bat / unnecessarily case-sensitive
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:07:25.676Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
overtype|ada|0.2.0
python|don|0.7.0
theme-dark-plus-contrast|k3a|0.1.101
cpptools|ms-|0.13.0
monitor-file|rko|1.0.1

(4 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to Reproduce:

0. assume there is such line in a *.bat file 
rem set SERVER_VERSION=5.7
1. set cursor on it, and uncomment with "Ctrl+/"
expected:
set SERVER_VERSION=5.7
actual result:
REM rem set SERVER_VERSION=5.7

Looks like uncomment is unnecessarily case-sensitive. It should uncomment despite it is 'rem' or 'REM'. I don't care whether with next "Ctrl+/" it will add Upper-Case 'REM' instead of 'rem' - it is not problem.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Error when I open integrated terminal on macOS
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: 10.12.6 (Sierra)

Error: The terminal process command `/bin/false -l` failed to launch (exit code: 1)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open integrated terminal
2. Verify that error pops up at top of the screen.

Workaround:
Seems that /bin/false wasn't a file on my computer. There was /usr/bin/false, but using that path in settings still gave the same error.
 
In the end I overwrote the default settings for the integrated terminal to be "terminal.integrated.shell.osx": "bash" and then it launched as normal.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Related Issues?:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14528
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14768

data.title: Allow terminal environment variables to be unset via terminal.integrated.env.windows

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Context: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/35550

```js
  "terminal.integrated.env.windows": {
    "LANG": null
  },
```

This follows the plan set forward for setting the env in the extension API too, see https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/20446#issuecomment-314267087 and https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/30352

data.title: Installed theme only available in one window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (81fc22ec957de26d2bf6aada3f16f04e0164741c, 2017-10-03T23:17:52.245Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.16362
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vsc-material-theme|Equ|1.0.4

(1 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open two workspaces
2. In one of the windows install a new theme
3. Reload Window
4. Change theme to newly installed theme
-> the other window still has the old theme, when you want to change to the new theme explicitly, it's not in the list of available themes

This behavior is different from when I re-launch VS Code with the theme already installed. All theme changes are taking affect across all windows.


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Workpace folder: add a command to the context menu to edit folder settings
data.body:
We could surface an action in the context menu of a root folder to open the settings editor for that folder.

/cc @isidorn @sandy081

data.title: Typing into readonly settings editor should show affordance
data.body: People that are not aware of the left hand settings editor being readonly should maybe get some hint how our settings work. We should explore what we can do here with the editor API (e.g. show a tooltip?).

data.title: Settings: context menu on setting in readonly editor should offer same actions as edit icon
data.body: This would make it easier to copy a setting over to the right hand side by just showing the same entries we show when you click on the edit "pencil" icon on the left.

data.title: Surface "Workspace" and "Folder" settings in File menu
data.body: We should bring back entries to the File menu for accessing workspace and folder settings.

data.title: Open full settings editor when clicking on settings.json in explorer
data.body: To help people that are struggling with defining workspace level settings by using the explorer. This probably needs a setting to disable for people that know what they are doing.

data.title: Letter spacing decoration: cursor offset is wrong
data.body:
Hello,

This feature was working really great, but recently I retry to use the letter-spacing and the cursor is now offset without changing my code.
I seems the letter-spacing is applied to the text decoration for example 'aaabc', so if I set letter-spacing to -4px for 'aaa' the text is correctly reduced, but if the cursor position is before b, then cursor position doesn't changed and the cursor is now after b.

Do I need to change something to my code or is it a vscode bug ?

Thank you in advance for your help.

A previous issue comment was added, but the issue wasn't reopened since april:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1925

Any info about the problem ?

data.title: When copying from csvode to some other editor (MS Word, Evernote and so on) the formatting is kept
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1 (1.16.1)
- OS Version: OSX 10.13

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Copy some part of the code, to MS Word
2. The Formating (font-size, color, background) everything is kept.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

As somebody coming from sublime its anoying, if i want to copy some part of the code, usualy translation strings to some editor, ms word, evernote or something else i want only the string without the formating.

I know the reason why this is im actually copying HTML and MS word and evernote try to keep the formating when you paste HTML but its still anoying.

In word you can choose to paste it without the formating but in other software you cannot.
I dont know is there a solution for this type of problem because for the technology used by vscode.

data.title: Fuzzy search doing a bad job of prioritizing search results
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:24:39.530Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.3.2
prettier-vscode|esb|0.24.0
atom-keybindings|ms-|3.0.2
vscode-todo-highlight|way|0.5.11

(1 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to Reproduce:

If you've got a large code base, the fuzzy search picks up too much noise and doesn't prioritize the sensible results.

For example, I have a file `settings.html` that's in a directory called `participants`. So I search for `parti settings`.

Here's what VSCode shows:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/362711/31176719-18c1a692-a914-11e7-97bd-4c785025d48d.png)

vs. Atom (with the file I'm after listed second):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/362711/31176763-41b1dc3e-a914-11e7-9740-65177e18cf17.png)

This seems to have been an issue for a long time, but related issues have been closed without fixing it. e.g. https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/968

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Spell check commit messages

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
For longer commit messages it would be great to have a spell checker there. Ideally, VSCode would provide that out of the box but if the direction is to leave spell checking up to extensions (and there are already some great ones out there, like [Spell Right](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ban.spellright) by @bartosz-antosik), there could be an API for that.

Possibly related: Offline spell checker for VSCode #20266

data.title: [html] Allow to ignoring base href

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:24:39.530Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0

I'd like to disable the integration for `<base href="/some-path/">`.
Right now the editor 'thinks' it should 'link' paths and prepend it with the base href, but this is only applicable when the application is deployed, since then it's running on a sub-directory.

How to reproduce:

1. Create two files: `index.html` and `script.js` in the same directory
0. Add `<base href="/some_path/"> to the index.html
0. Add `<script src="script.js"></script> to the index.html
0. Try to `cmd + click` or `ctrl + click` on the script.js

**Expected**
Navigate to `./script.js`

**Actual**
Navigation blocked: 
```
Unable to open 'script.js': File not found (/Users/....../some-path/script.js).
```

data.title: editor.formatOnSave not applying Eslint rules anymore
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install extensions: esbenp.prettier-vscode, dbaeumer.vscode-eslint

2. Set following vscode configuration, .eslintrc and node dependencies

```
// vscode settings
// Place your settings in this file to overwrite default and user settings.
{
  "editor.formatOnSave": true,
  "mocha.enabled": true,
  "prettier.singleQuote": true,
  "prettier.trailingComma": "all",
  "prettier.parser": "flow",
  "javascript.format.enable": false
}
```
```
// .eslintrc
{
  "extends": ["prettier"],
  "parser": "babel-eslint",
  "env": {
    "es6": true
  },
  "plugins": ["prettier"],
  "rules": {
    "prettier/prettier": "error",
  }
}
```
```
// package.json
    ....
    "babel-core": "^6.26.0",
    "babel-eslint": "^8.0.1",
    "babel-preset-env": "^1.6.0",
    "eslint": "^4.8.0",
    "eslint-config-prettier": "^2.6.0",
    "eslint-plugin-prettier": "^2.3.1",
    "prettier": "^1.7.4", ...
```

2. Create a new document with the following code for example and save:
```
const greet = { msg: 'Hello, how are you ?', type: 'hello' };
const { msg, type } = greet;
```

3. You will see that the editor formatting does not apply the eslint rules, although it recognises the error generated afterwards.

4. * if the following vscode setting properties are set, it works. But I don't want to disable the editor.formatOnSave property.
```
"editor.formatOnSave": true,
"eslint.autoFixOnSave": false,
```

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Not possible

data.title: Debugging of source files with source maps in subfolders work, but not in project root
data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. First create a project with typescript files being compiled to javascript **not in** the project root
2. Configure launch.json like so:
```{
  "configurations": [
    {
      "name": "app",
      "outFiles": [
        "${workspaceRoot}/app/app.js"
      ],
      "program": "${workspaceRoot}/app/app.ts",
      "request": "launch",
      "sourceMaps": true,
      "type": "node"
    }
  ],
  "version": "0.2.0"
}
```
3. The debugging works without the problem
4. Then create a project with typescript files being compiled to javascript **in** the project root
5. Configure launch.json like so:
```{
  "configurations": [
    {
      "name": "app",
      "outFiles": [
        "${workspaceRoot}/app.js"
      ],
      "program": "${workspaceRoot}/app.ts",
      "request": "launch",
      "sourceMaps": true,
      "type": "node"
    }
  ],
  "version": "0.2.0"
}
```
6. Now the debugging doesn't work: `Cannot launch program '/Techs/projects/bleeve/frontend-router/app.ts'; setting the 'outDir or outFiles' attribute might help.`

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Are touchBar commands really, always editor aware?
